And even if you're not a farmer or know someone who is, you can always buy the fertilizer from several different places so as to not get caught. But apparently such a simple concept is too much for your poor brain to handle.

 Since you obviously agree with regulating dynamite, guns and even fertilizer, why not take it one step further? Over 2000 people get stabbed to death in the US each year, why not regulate kitchen knives?

Never bought the "biggest massacre" bit myself. I can think of few others myself. Okalhoma City, Sand Creek, Wounded Knee, witch burnings, and who knows how many slaves, Chinese (railroad workers), and American-Japanese (WWII camps) died do to unjust acts.

Yep, it was not the "biggest massacre in school history/US history". It WAS, however, the biggest massacre involving a shooter in US history - before that it was sometime in the 80's in Texas. I do see that many anti-gun people are trying to tout this as the biggest massacre in US history, and I think they do an injustice to all those in other, larger killings involving things besides a gun - like the dynamite in the OP.
Ooaman

For example, just mention the low murder rates in Canada and Switzerland, where gun ownership is legal, and they scatter like cockroaches.

 
 Canadians don't usually go out of their way to shoot others. Most of their shooting is in the woods while hunting deer or other wildlife animals. This is because hunting is a big deal in Canada.
 Guns that are used in the US that most adolescence use in school shootings are not the kind of guns you use in hunting...
 Also, the situation you posted of the animal poop bomb in '27 wasn't a case of a student going out and blowing up his fellow class mates. It was an issue over property tax that the guy blamed the school for.
daewoo

**
 Yeah, right, and these days everybody has a right to buy and carry dynamite. You can get it at your neighbourhood gunshop, right? Haw!

 
 Gun stores don't sell dynamite. Pretty much every feed elevator and farmers coop in the country does, though. I still have half a box I bought a few years ago. It costs about $1 per stick. Demolition explosives can also typically be purchased easily. They are extremely useful for agricultural applications. My duck pond was made by stacking several bags of ammonium nitrate, saturating it with fuel oil, and detonating 4 sticks of dynamite that were stuck in the bags.
 
 
And although it is true that psychopaths will use everything and anything, from bows and arrows to fertilizer, so as to cruelly murder even innocent infants, two wrongs do not make a right. Heck, just try to buy enough fertilizer to make a bomb with, post Oklahoma City!! If so for dynamite and fertilizer, why not for guns?

 
 I have bought ammonium nitrate twice this year. Both times I bought FAR more than was used in OK city. The guy who does the farming on my land puts it on the fields. What McVeigh used was NOTHING compared to what gets dumped on fields.
 
 What gets me about ammonium nitrate is that we keep seeing these moronic attempts ot control its sale and none of them ever get implemented. Even when laws get passed the people who are supposed to be enforcing them seem to recognize, even if the XXXXXX pushing for the laws do not, that if you restrict the sale of the most common fertilizer in the US, you are going to have some problems. 
 
 Personally it always surprised me that anybody would buy ammonium nitrate to build bombs. It would be easier to stop and steal it from a farmer. That is what is in those big blue boxes you see in their fields i the spring time.
mae

Never bought the "biggest massacre" bit myself. I can think of few others myself. Okalhoma City, Sand Creek, Wounded Knee, witch burnings, and who knows how many slaves, Chinese (railroad workers), and American-Japanese (WWII camps) died do to unjust acts.

 
 I believe it is the biggest "massacre" by a lone gun man.

But perhaps the thought that access to explosives, even fertilizers, has tightened up severely since McVeigh and 9/11 is "just too much for your poor brain to handle", eh!?! 
 
 

 And as for dynamite, these days we have a thing called the Internet and guess what, if you Google "making dynamite" the very first hit shows how you can make dynamite from common household materials. Oops.

 
 **
 Have you ever handled nitroglycerine, or tried to make an Improvised Explosive Device from an internet message? If not, then I strongly encourage you to do so, and at your earliest convenience.
 
 

 Since you obviously agree with regulating dynamite, guns and even fertilizer, why not take it one step further? Over 2000 people get stabbed to death in the US each year, why not regulate kitchen knives?

 
 **
 How often does a schoolroom full of kids, a crowded restaurant, or a university campus, suffer a wholesale massacre by a knife-wielding psycho? How many deranged snipers kill their victims by throwing knives at them? Do you have as many as two clues to rub together?
 
 [quote]
 Fact is that you advocate infringing on other people's rights just because you're scared.[/qute]
 
 **
 What smelly little right-wing offensive. You wouldn't be clamouring to carry a gun if you weren't a coward who needs a gun to give him power over others. I don't, and even people who are only physically frail or even disabled do not run to hide behind a gun like you do. If Loo (sp.?) hadn't been a weak emotional cripple he wouldn't have bought and used his guns. Fear and power are the only reasons that people buy handguns. Fear can be legitimate in some cases, but most of the time it's just general anxiety and paranoia. Power is fine if it's limited to target shooting; once it becomes an aid to a macho identity, it becomes a sickness. Just imagine all the gun-culture types who fantasize about killing 'bad guys' and 'defending the innocent' and gunning down psychos to universal applause. They probably masturbate to those images every night. Do you?
 
 

 Why don't you just move to North Korea?

 
 **
 Gee, you're just a fountainhead of witty retorts, aren't you? Word of advice--don't ever ask to see your IQ score.
 
 

 I'm pretty sure that the people there aren't allowed to own guns (or anything else for that matter), and look at how safe and happy the people there are. 

 
 **
 Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and most European countries, not to mention South Korea, etc., have hand-gun restrictions which bring their murder rates, and gun-death rates, way, way down below that of the USA, without being even remotely like North Korea, politically. What silly guff!! 
 
 

 It's amazing to see how people lose the ability for rational thought when it comes to the government. They actually believe that this entity known as the government will protect them, and cure them of all their ails.

We have a saying here in Holland: "Zoals de waard is vertrouwd hij zijn gasten".
 It basically means that a person trusts other people as much as he trusts himself. I think this is very applicable to the people on the anti-gun side of the debate. They don't trust other people with guns because of their own insecurities.
Count Otto

For example, just mention the low murder rates in Canada and Switzerland, where gun ownership is legal, and they scatter like cockroaches.

 
 All crime rates are low in Switzerland. Coincidentally it is one of the individually richest countries in the world, has a great standard of living and some of the most draconian laws in Europe when people do offend.
 
 Even so there was a mass shooting there in 2001 when man walked into the local parliament building with his national service assault rifle and killed 14 people. On another thread someone suggested that as the UK has a population of 60 million and the US has 300 million, the fact that the US had a multiple shooting (more than 5 people) every 2 years (or so), the UK would be expected to have one every 10 years. Switzerland has a population of 7 million, suggesting that if population has any bearing, Switzerland should have such a shooting every 84 years.

the first thing I heard said in regards to that both on TV and on these boards was someone calling for the right to concealed carry.

 My point was that the media, the government and the people shouldn't start screaming at the top of their lungs that this is the biggest massacre ever to advance their own anti-gun agenda's, while at the same time omitting the fact that 80 years earlier something even worse happened.
 
 You then come up with this little gem: 
 
 Oh please. It's not "gun grabbers" that were talking about it as the biggest U.S. massacre, it was the sensational headline hungry media.

 Which is of course utter BS, because that would imply that even if a gun grabber managed to come up with this erroneous statement by himself, the moment he would say it on TV it would be the media that really said it and not the gun grabber.

My point was that the media, the government and the people shouldn't start screaming at the top of their lungs that this is the biggest massacre ever to advance their own anti-gun agenda's, while at the same time omitting the fact that 80 years earlier something even worse happened.

 
 I have to agree with Master Shake. It requires no agenda from "gun grabbers" for the media to sensationalize a story, or for gov't officials to use the opportunity for their own political gain.
 
 I also think that there's a difference between a farmer having access to dynamite and a student having access to guns.
